name: syntax if
class: top

# .left[The _if condition_  Syntax]

and how it works
--
.pull-left[
```{r demo_if_sin, include=FALSE}
is_biryani_good <- FALSE

if(is_biryani_good == FALSE){
  "Add more mirchi ka salan"
}
```

```{r echo=FALSE}
decorate("demo_if_sin") %>% 
  flair_funs(color = "Coral", underline = TRUE) %>% 
  flair_input_vals(background = "Cornflowerblue") %>% 
  flair("(") %>%
  flair(")") %>%
  flair("{",color = "green") %>%
  flair("}",color = "green") %>%
  knit_print.with_flair()
```

]
--
.pull-right[
_Things to remember_

a) The conditional statement and its length<br>
b) goes inside ()<br>
c) expressions/code to run if condition is true<br>
d) expression/code goes inside {}<br>

_What happens when_

a) length of `is_biryani_good` is more than one ?<br>
b) if the condition is not met?
]

class: left

# .center[Pop Quiz  <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width = 5% align = "center">]

Which of the following conditional statements will _not generate_ a warning if used with the `if(){}` function. Consider the following code before choosing the answer. 

> x <- c(7,8,6,9)<br>
> y <- 75

.pull-left[
A) x < 70 <br>
B) y < 100
]

.pull-right[
C) x < y <br>
D) y > 100

]
???

B and D will not generate an error, however D is an unsatisfactory condition for the if case to be executed.
---
name: explaining else
class: left

# _if(condition){expr 1}else{expr 2}_

made for each other
--
.pull-left[

```{r demo_else, include=FALSE}
if(is_biryani_good == TRUE){
  "This is good biryani, visit this plsce again"    ### first expression
}else{
  "Why did I pay the money" ### second expression
}
```

```{r echo=FALSE}
decorate("demo_else") %>% 
  flair("else", color = "Cornflowerblue") %>% 
  flair_input_vals(color = "Red") %>% 
  flair("Why did I pay the money") %>% 
  knit_print.with_flair()
```
]

.pull-right[
What happens if the if condition is not satisfied?<br>
<iframe src="https://giphy.com/embed/w48WeMIN73QsM" width="480" height="356" frameBorder="0" class="giphy-embed" allowFullScreen></iframe><p><a href="https://giphy.com/gifs/harry-potter-snape-w48WeMIN73QsM">via GIPHY</a></p>
]

name: ifelse and if_else intor
class: top

# _ifelse()_ and _if_else()_
There is one important difference, we will come to it later

.pull-left[
```{r demo_ifelse, include=FALSE}

x <- c(7,2,6,4,8,9,10,10,1,3)

ifelse(x >=5, 
       "Good Biryani",
       "Bad Biryani"
       )

```

```{r echo=FALSE}
decorate("demo_ifelse") %>% 
  flair_funs(color = "Coral") %>%
  flair("x >=5", background = "Cornflowerblue") %>% 
  flair("Good Biryani", background = "ForestGreen") %>% 
  flair("Bad Biryani", background = "GreenYellow") %>% 
  knit_print.with_flair()

```
]

.pull-right[
Notice any difference from the __`if(){}else{}` __ statement?
Discuss!
]

???
 Talk about the dplyr package
 
 Talk about how the length of condition need not be one.
 
 Why is using ifelse() or if_else() more convenient than using if(){}
